In these cases we adopted the parameters (namely centroid coordinates, position angle, major/minor axis length and magnitude) estimated through <i>SExtractor </i>from the HST <i>F</i>606<i>W</i> image. </p>\n<p>We parameterised the mass of cluster galaxies with the dual pseudo isothermal elliptical mass distribution (hereafter dPIE, <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R47\">Kassiola &amp; Kovner 1993</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R49\">Kneib et&#160;al. 1996</a>), following <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R44\">Jullo et&#160;al. (2007); </a><a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R17\">Brainerd et&#160;al. (1996)</a> and several other authors. The dPIE profile is given by <a name=\"FD9\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq172.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(9)</span></span>The dPIE cut radius can be roughly considered as the half mass radius<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FN10\">9</a></sup>. The two-dimensional surface mass density distribution is obtained by integrating Eq.&#160;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FD9\">9</a>) (see also  <a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R56\">Limousin et&#160;al. 2005</a>): <a name=\"FD10\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq173.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(10)</span></span>where <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> is a characteristic central velocity dispersion, which cannot be simply related to the measured velocity dispersion (<a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R28\">El&#237;asd&#243;ttir et&#160;al. 2007</a>). </p>\n<p>The free parameters in the dPIE model are thus the core radius <i>r</i><sub>core</sub>, the truncation radius <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub>, and the characteristic velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub>. For elliptical galaxies, the Faber-Jackson relation (hereafter FJ, <a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R33\">Faber &amp; Jackson 1976</a>) predicts that the central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> is proportional to the galaxy luminosity <i>L</i> following the scaling relation <a name=\"FD11\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq179.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(11)</span></span>where <i>L</i><sup>&#160;<i>&#8902;</i>&#160;</sup> is a given arbitrary galaxy luminosity and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq181.png\"></span> is its corresponding dPIE velocity dispersion; our reference magnitude is <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq182.png\"></span>. We will assume the following scaling relations for the characteristic radii of the dPIE profile: <a name=\"FD12\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq183.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(12)</span></span>here again <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq184.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq185.png\"></span> are the dPIE scale parameters for a <i>L</i><sup>&#160;<i>&#8902;</i>&#160;</sup> galaxy. The exponent of the scaling relation for <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub> determines how the mass scales with respect to the light distribution. If <i>&#945;</i>&#160;=&#160;0.5 the mass-to-light ratio (<i>ML</i>) of the galaxy is constant and independent of its luminosity, as usually assumed in strong and weak lensing analyses (<a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R90\">Richard et&#160;al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R43\">Hoekstra et&#160;al. 2004</a>). Assuming <i>&#945;</i>&#160;=&#160;0.8 one obtains that the mass-to-light ratio scales with luminosity according to <i>ML</i>&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>L</i><sup>0.3</sup> (<a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R39\">Halkola et&#160;al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R74\">Natarajan &amp; Kneib 1997</a>). In this paper we will assume <i>&#945;</i>&#160;=&#160;0.5, but in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S18\">3.7</a> we will compare the results obtained under this assumption with those obtained by assuming <i>&#945;</i>&#160;=&#160;0.8. We did not test alternative scaling relations for the cluster galaxy core radius, since we did not identify any reliable constraint on the galaxy inner mass distribution. </p>\n<p>The galaxy parameters optimised in the lens modelling are the central velocity dispersion and the truncation radius, whereas the other dPIE parameters (ellipticity, position and orientation of the halo) were tied to the values inferred from the analysis of the galaxy light profile. </p>\n<p>The normalisation for the core radius scaling was set to <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq190.png\"></span>&#160;arcsec &#160;&#8771;&#160;0.15&#160;kpc, while for the velocity dispersion normalisation <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq181.png\"></span> we adopted the uniform prior [120.0&#8211;200.0]&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup>. Following the relation between luminosity and velocity dispersion found by <a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R9\">Bernardi et&#160;al. (2003)</a>, our reference magnitude corresponds to a velocity dispersion &#160;&#8771;&#160;170&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup> for an early-type galaxy. The prior <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq193.png\"></span>&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup> adopts a conservative upper limit; the lower limit was decreased to 120.0&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup> to take into account the recent findings of <a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R77\">Natarajan et&#160;al. (2009)</a> about the difference in the dPIE velocity dispersion between cluster galaxies in the core or in the outer regions. </p>\n<p>The truncation radius normalisation determines the steepness of the galaxy mass profile. A common and reasonable approach is to fix it to a likely value (see R09 and <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R59\">Limousin et&#160;al. 2009</a>), since usually the strong lensing system does not provide enough constraints on the mass distribution of the small scale perturbers. However, the mass distribution of early-type galaxies in high-density environment is likely to be truncated compared to field galaxies with an equivalent luminosity (<a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R40\">Halkola et&#160;al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R57\">Limousin et&#160;al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R75\">Natarajan et&#160;al. 2002</a>). For this reason, the truncation of cluster galaxy halos could be different from one case to another. </p>\n<p>Thanks to the peculiar lensing system of Abell&#160;611, an estimate of the truncation radius normalisation will be derived in one dedicated tests (see Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S18\">3.7</a>). The perturbing galaxy labelled 1 in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a> was optimised singularly, since the strong constraints on its Einstein radius provided by the conjugate systems B.4/B.5 enable a reliable estimate of its mass distribution. Because however neither R09 or <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R78\">Newman et&#160;al. (2009)</a> unlinked this galaxy from the cluster member catalogue, we ran a test to verify if and how this single perturber can affect the global test results. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>3.6. Modelling of the BCG</h3>\n<p>The BCG itself was included in the lens modelling as a dPIE halo. However, although the BCG was parameterised with the same mass functional as the cluster members, its mass model refers only to its <i>baryonic </i>content, while for cluster galaxies what is actually modelled is the <i>total </i>mass. As pointed out in the work of <a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R69\">Miralda-Escude (1995)</a> (see also <a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R58\">Limousin et&#160;al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R27\">Dubinski 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R63\">Mellier et&#160;al. 1993</a>), the dark matter halo of the BCG is indistinguishable from the cluster halo in the lens modelling. </p>\n<p>For this reason a direct comparison of the measured central velocity dispersion of the BCG to the fitted <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,dPIE</sub> would lead to incorrect conclusions: the former is determined by the combined contribution of the dark and baryonic matter, while the latter is a fitting parameter referred to as a &#8220;stellar-only&#8221; BCG component. </p>\n<p>The dPIE mass parameters &#8211; characteristic central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,dPIE</sub> and truncation radius <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub> &#8211; were optimised for the BCG in the ranges [100.0&#8211;350.0]&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup> and [8.0&#8211;31.0]&#160;arcsec (&#160;&#8771;&#160;[34.6&#8211;134.2]&#160;kpc), respectively: these ranges take into account the results obtained through a strong lensing analysis by R09 and by N09, to allow a comparison with their results (see Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S20\">5</a>). </p>\n<p>The degeneracy between the central baryonic mass budget and the dark matter content with regard to the strong lensing results is currently well established. It is still to be discussed whether the choice of the BCG mass profile can impact the derived cluster mass parameters. To assess this point, we ran a dedicated test adopting the S&#233;rsic profile to parametrise the BCG mass. The S&#233;rsic mass profile has the same functional form as Eq.&#160;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FD8\">8</a>), but the parameter &#931;<sub>e</sub> refers to the mass density at the effective radius <i>r</i><sub>e</sub>. </p>\n<p>For the modelling of the BCG we adopted the morphological parameters derived from the two-dimensional fitting of the BCG luminosity profile obtained with <i>Galfit</i>, listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T4\">4</a>. We optimised the S&#233;rsic index within &#160;&#177;&#160;10% of the best-fitting value, to take into account the measurement errors. After some preliminary tests, we chose as lower limit to the &#931;<sub>e</sub> optimisation range the value of 2&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>8</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>&#160;&#8201;&#160;kpc<sup>-2</sup> to derive a total mass for the BCG similar to the mass derived when modelling the BCG as a dPIE profile, for a safer comparison between the results obtained in both cases (see the total projected mass maps and the surface mass density profiles shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F7\">7</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;7</span></a>\n              <p>(<i>Top Panels</i>) Comparison between the projected mass maps obtained when modelling the BCG with a dPIE profile (<i>left panel</i>, case 1 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>) or with a S&#233;rsic profile (<i>right panel</i>, case 7 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). See Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a> and the text for further details. (<i>Bottom Panels</i>) Comparison between the surface mass density profiles for the BCG halo (<i>left panel</i>) and the NFW cluster scale halo (<i>right panel</i>) derived when modelling the BCG with a dPIE profile (red solid line, case 1) or with a S&#233;rsic profile (green dashed line, case 7).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>3.7. Strong lensing results</h3>\n<p>We present in this section the results of the parametric analysis of the strong lensing system in Abell&#160;611. In order to assess the effect of the galaxy parameterisation on the best-fitting results for the cluster-scale halo we performed several tests, changing the manner of including the cluster galaxies. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"T5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;5</span></a>\n              <p> Median values for the total mass parameters, obtained with the strong lensing analysis.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;8</span></a>\n              <p>Scatter plots for the NFW parameters <i>r</i><sub>s</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> obtained for some representative cases. The numbering of the cases corresponds to the numbering in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. The red point distribution marks the 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence level for the two parameters. The green stars indicate the best-fit values; the error-bars refer to the 1<i>&#963;</i> statistical uncertainty. We used the same knot systems as inputs and the same priors on the cluster halo mass distribution in all the six cases; the only differences were the modelling and the parameterisation of the cluster galaxies and of the BCG. The probability distribution in case 4 appears squeezed because it crushed on the lower limit for the BCG characteristic central velocity dispersion. The lens model results for the cases shown here are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. </p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>We list below the characteristics of the lens modelling for the cases presented in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>.</p>\n<p><ul class=\"dash\">\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 1</i>: both the reference truncation radius and the reference\n                central velocity dispersion for the cluster&#8211;galaxy scaling relation were optimised\n                in the ranges [4&#8211;12] arcsec and [120.0&#8211;200.0] km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup>, respectively. In\n                this case, and when not otherwise stated, the mass parameters of galaxy n.&#160;1 in\n                  Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a> were individually optimised (the\n                optimization ranges were <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub>&#160;&#8712;&#160; [0.5&#8211;8.0]&#160;arcsec and\n                  <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub>&#160;&#8712;&#160; [90.0&#8211;190.0]&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup>) and the\n                exponent <i>&#945;</i> in Eq.&#160;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FD12\">12</a>) was set equal to 0.5. </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 2</i>: the reference central velocity dispersion was optimised,\n                whereas the reference truncation radius was fixed to the value of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq320.png\"></span>&#160;arcsec. The exponent <i>&#945;</i> in\n                  Eq.&#160;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FD12\">12</a>) was assumed to be equal\n                to 0.8 (therefore the Mass to Light ratio <i>ML</i> is &#160;&#8733;&#160;0.3). </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 3</i>: as in case 2, but we assumed that <i>&#945;</i>&#160;=&#160;0.5\n                (therefore <i>ML</i> is constant and independent of the galaxy\n                luminosity). </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 4</i>: a constant <i>ML</i> scaling relation was\n                assumed for all cluster galaxies. This is the only case in which the galaxy n.&#160;1 in\n                  Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a> was not individually optimised. </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 5</i>: we adopted the same lens model as in case 3, but we\n                included as constraint the candidate lens system individuated by R09 and by N09,\n                labelled D in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a> and in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">A.1</a> in the Appendix. </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 6</i>: a constant <i>ML</i> scaling relation was\n                adopted for all the cluster galaxies, with the exception of those that can be tested\n                through the strong lensing analysis, for their direct effect on some lensed images\n                (galaxies 1 to 6 in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a>), which were\n                individually optimised. </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              <p><i>Case 7</i>: the same lens model as in case 1 was assumed, but the BCG\n                was modelled with an elliptical S&#233;rsic profile. </p>\n            </li>\n          </ul>It is not redundant to verify whether the mass distributions of the perturbing galaxies differ from the distribution that can be derived adopting a scaling relation, since, as shown in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T4\">4</a>, these galaxies have significantly different light profiles. Moreover, the intrinsic scatter in the FJ scaling relation between velocity dispersion and luminosity for early-type galaxies is not taken into account in the strong lensing modelling. We stress that in all the aforementioned cases, except for case 7, the BCG was modelled as a dPIE halo (see Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S17\">3.6</a> for more details on the BCG modelling). </p>\n<p>The results of the strong lensing analysis of Abell&#160;611 for the aforementioned cases are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. The critical and the caustic lines and the images predicted in all tested cases are shown in the Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F15\">B.1</a> in the Appendix. Evidently depending on the different lens modelling the results on the cluster total mass can change by up to 15%, so the parameterisation of the perturber galaxies and of the BCG has a non-negligible impact on the strong lensing results; the degeneracy between cluster and galaxy mass parameters is shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F8\">8</a>. In particular, a strong degeneracy is found between the fiducial BCG central velocity dispersion and the cluster concentration/total mass (see the top panels in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F9\">9</a>). </p>\n<p>It is remarkable that the resulting NFW cluster parameters depend not only on the BCG baryonic mass, but also on the BCG mass profile. In case 1 and in case 7 we show the results obtained by modelling the BCG with a dPIE or with a S&#233;rsic profile, respectively; the corresponding projected mass maps and surface mass density profiles are shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F7\">7</a>. The BCG mass derived in both cases is similar, but the inferred cluster parameters are significantly different. In particular, the cluster total mass is larger and the NFW concentration parameter lower when modelling the BCG with a S&#233;rsic profile. This result can be explained by considering that, in this case, the surface mass density of the best-fitting S&#233;rsic profile in the BCG central region is larger compared with the best-fitting dPIE profile (see the bottom left panel in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F7\">7</a>). The inferred concentration for the cluster scale halo in the latter case will thus be higher because of the degeneracy between the cluster halo and the BCG mass with respect to the lens total mass, which is the quantity constrained by the gravitational lensing. </p>\n<p>However, the estimates of the <i>total </i>mass in the central regions (where the strong lensing constraints are found) derived in the different cases mutually agree, (see the discussion in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S19\">4</a>); the modelling of the galactic component appears to have a negligible impact on the total mass results in the central region. Conversely, the differences among several of the test cases arise when the cluster mass is extrapolated outside the region that is accessible through the strong lensing analysis. </p>\n<p>This is another evidence that the modelling of the BCG stellar mass can directly affect the cluster total mass results: in order to obtain reliable mass estimates through a parametric strong lensing analysis, it is crucial to break the degeneracy between the different lens components. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;9</span></a>\n              <p>Scatter plots of cluster-halo parameters (<i>c</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>M</i><sub>tot</sub>) versus parameters of the modelling of either the BCG or the perturber galaxy n.1 (hereafter P1, see text for details). Here we show the posterior probability distributions obtained in a representative case (case 1 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The plotted parameters are: 1.&#160;the NFW concentration parameter <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> versus the BCG fiducial central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,BCG</sub> (<i>top left panel</i>); 2.&#160;the cluster halo mass <i>M</i><sub>tot</sub> versus <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,BCG</sub><i>top right panel</i>); 3.&#160;the NFW concentration parameter <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> versus the fiducial central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,P1</sub> of the galaxy P1 (<i>bottom left panel</i>); 4.&#160; the cluster halo mass <i>M</i><sub>tot</sub> versus <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,P1</sub> (<i>bottom right panel</i>). The contours show the 68%, 95% and 99% confidence levels. The colour code refers to the value of the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> estimator.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Despite the difference in the best-fitting results, all models return probability regions in the parameter space that are marginally consistent with each other. As previously found for the X-ray analysis, the strong lensing results appears relatively stable against possible systematic errors, which in this case are mainly constituted by modelling uncertainties. </p>\n<p>As stated before, the perturber galaxy n.1 (see Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a>) was individually optimised in all the tests that we ran, except in case&#160;4, due to the tight constraint on its mass distribution provided by the conjugated images&#160;B.4 and B.5. We found a mild degeneracy between the mass of this galaxy, the mass of the stellar content of the BCG, and the concentration of the NFW halo, as expected given the proximity of this perturber to the BCG (see the bottom panels in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F9\">9</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;10</span></a>\n              <p>Median values of the dPIE truncation radius <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub> vs. the characteristic dPIE central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> for the galaxies that perturb the strong lensing system of Abell&#160;611. The red triangles show the results obtained linking the galaxy parameters to the same scaling relation in the lens modelling (Case 4 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>), while the blue stars represent the results obtained optimising the galaxies individually (Case 6 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The grey dashed lines show the iso-density contours. The error bars indicate the 1<i>&#963;</i> uncertainty, while the cyan boxes indicate the 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence region for the results which refer to Case 4.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Moreover, in case 6 we optimised singularly the galaxies whose mass distribution can be constrained through the strong lensing effect alone. As it is evident from Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F10\">10</a>, optimising in wide ranges the dPIE parameters for these perturber galaxies returns, as expected, large uncertainties in the mass parameters. However, for some perturbers the parameters inferred through an individual optimisation appear to be incongruous with those predicted assuming the parameter scaling derived from the Faber-Jackson relation. It is reasonable to question whether neglecting the scatter associated to the galaxy parameter scaling relations in the strong lensing analysis could bias the inferred results. </p>\n<p>It seems likely that in most cases this bias, if any, can be safely negligible, as it is obvious by comparing case 1 to case 6. Nonetheless, in the presence of galaxies that strongly affect the strong lensing features, the biasing effect on the final results could be more significant (again, this is the case of the perturber galaxy labelled n.1 in this work, as can be seen by comparing case 1 to case 4). </p>\n<p>Regarding the strong lensing systems, all our models predict that the tangential arc (system A) originates by the large deformation of a single source located on a &#8220;naked cusp&#8221;, i.e. a tangential caustic extending outside the radial caustic (<a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R52\">Kormann et&#160;al. 1994</a>; <a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R7\">Bartelmann &amp; Loeb 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R94\">Rusin &amp; Ma 2001</a>). Naked cusps are a quite rare caustic configuration which mainly occurrs in highly elliptical lens systems whose surface density is only moderately above the critical surface density required for the production of multiple images (&#8220;marginal lenses&#8221;, <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R14\">Blandford &amp; Kochanek 1987</a>; <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R6\">Bartelmann 2000</a>), with a few naked cusps detected so far (<a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R55\">Lewis et&#160;al. 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR79\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R79\">Oguri et&#160;al. 2008</a>). Sources placed within the exposed tangential caustic form only three magnified images on the same side of the lens: this explains why the tangential arc in Abell&#160;611 has no counter-image. </p>\n<p>The position and the shape of the observed images are well reproduced by all our models, as is obvious from the low scatter both in the image and in the source plane resulting from the best-fit models: all tests returned low values of the reduced <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq327.png\"></span>) and of the image plane root-mean-square (rms<sub>i</sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;0.5&#160;arcsec) (see also the fitting results for a representative case &#8211; Case 1 &#8211; listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T6\">6</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"T6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;6</span></a>\n              <p>Fitting results of the source-plane optimisation.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In particular, the lens models of cases 4 and 7 (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>) predict a central image for the system B in a position almost coincident with a radial-oriented feature lying close to the centre of the BCG (see Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F11\">11</a> and the predicted central image in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F15\">B.1</a>; this central image was also indentified and interpreted by N09). However, since the detection of this feature is not certain, we did not include it as an additional constraint. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F11\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;11</span></a>\n              <p>ACS/HST snapshot of a radial-oriented feature, likely a central counter-image corresponding to System B; the BCG is visible [subtracted] in the left [right] panel.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Regarding the third system C, our identification of the positive parity counter-image, which follows R09, appears reliable owing to the very low scatter resulting for this system. Our models predict three additional counter-images: two of them should be located close to the BCG and to the galaxy n.1, and are predicted to be demagnified with respect to the identified image, so they are likely not detectable. A negative parity counter-image is predicted at about 2&#8211;3&#160;arcsec (depending on the different lens models) above the observed one. In that area there are no evident counter-images, but a faint one, identified with SExtractor (<i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#160;&#8771;&#160;3.9), whose position could be marginally compatible with the location of the predicted image. The flux ratio derived when modelling the BCG as a dPIE halo does not match the observed one well, while the images predicted when modelling the BCG with a S&#233;rsic profile follow the observed flux ratio more closely (see Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F12\">12</a>), because of the difference in the inferred mass for the galactic perturbers. This evidence would seem to favour the modelling of the BCG with a S&#233;rsic profile over the dPIE profile: but we aim to highlight that other explanations could be possible to the observed mismatch in the flux ratios for the images of the third system. For example, the effect of unresolved substructures along the line of sight would cause the dimming of the negative-parity image in cusp systems (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R48\">Keeton 2003</a>) (see also <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R79\">Oguri et&#160;al. 2008</a>). Another explanation could be the misidentification of the counter-image C.2, which would cause its predicted magnification to be incorrect. </p>\n<p>The candidate system D looks plausible considering the low scatter in the observed and predicted positions. The redshift estimates of the four knot systems are marginally consistent. However, the results of the cluster mass parameters are not significantly changed by including this system. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>4. Comparison between X-ray and strong lensing results</h2>\n<p>We will compare here the results obtained with the strong lensing and the X-ray analyses for the galaxy cluster Abell&#160;611. The left panel in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F13\">13</a> shows the probability distributions of the NFW profile parameters obtained with both analyses, while the right panel compares the corresponding projected mass profiles. For the strong lensing analysis we show the 3<i>&#963;</i> region, marginalised over the other fit parameters, derived in case 1 and in case 7 of Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. The best-fit values for the NFW profile parameters and for the corresponding mass are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T7\">7</a>. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F12\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;12</span></a>\n            <p>Comparison between the ACS/HST <i>F</i>606<i>W</i> observation (<i>left panel</i>), smoothed with a 3 <i>FWHM </i>pixel Gaussian filter for a better visualisation of the faint lensed image C.1 (marked with a white circle), and the reconstructed image systems predicted from the lens models in case 1 ((<i>middle panel</i>): in this case the BCG was modelled as a dPIE potential) and case 7 ((<i>right panel</i>): the BCG was parametrised with a S&#233;rsic profile &#8211; see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The white circles in the middle and right panels mark the centre of the predicted counter-images. The black circle in the left panel indicates a candidate counter-image of C.1, indentified with SExtractor. The three images are WCS-aligned; the flux scale of the second and the third panel is the same. </p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>To unfold this issue, higher resolution observations of the Sunyaev-Zel&#8217;dovich effect measurements towards this cluster would play a crucial role, because they would allow us with the X-ray data to estimate the projected axis ratio along the line of sight. Obviously the best-fit values for the scale radius and the concentration parameter derived with the X-ray and the strong lensing analyses are consistent within a 2&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#963;</i> range; however, the results derived from the strong lensing analysis in case 7 better agree with the X-ray estimates. In particular, the strong lensing mass estimates for Abell&#160;611 are lower than the mass derived through our X-ray analysis which is lower by up to a factor of two. </p>\n<p>\n        <a name=\"T7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;7</span></a>\n            <p>Comparison of the mass results obtained with the X-ray and the strong lensing analyses. </p>\n          </div></div>\n      </p>\n<p>This result is somehow surprising, since so far the discrepancies found between strong lensing and X-ray mass estimates have the opposite trend, with the smaller X-ray masses (see e.g. <a name=\"InR91\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R91\">Richard et&#160;al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R84\">Peng et&#160;al. 2009</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R37\">Gitti et&#160;al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R62\">Medezinski et&#160;al. 2007</a>). However, the mass estimates for Abell&#160;611 derived in three representative cases agree very well in the region where the strong lensing constraints are found (approximately <i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;100&#160;kpc), as is obvious from the right panel of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F13\">13</a>. On the other hand, the strong lensing mass is smaller than the X-ray one when extrapolating the mass profile in the cluster peripheral regions. </p>\n<p>This result confirms that strong lensing provides a robust estimate of the <i>total </i>mass of the cluster (DM plus baryonic component) in the central region; it moreover suggests that the disagreement between the X-ray and the strong lensing masses can be related to the incorrect estimate of the total baryonic mass budget (for example, the reader can compare the results obtained in case 4 and in case 1 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>) or of its radial profile, because the resulting cluster mass distribution will be incorrectly steepened (with a higher concentration parameter and a smaller scale radius) to account for the missing baryonic mass component. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F13\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;13</span></a>\n            <p>(<i>Left panel</i>) Comparison of the NFW parameter probability distribution obtained with our X-ray and strong lensing analyses. The X-ray and the strong lensing contours show the 3-<i>&#963;</i> confidence level (the strong lensing results were marginalised over the other fit parameters). The X-ray contours were obtained deriving the X-ray background from the blank-sky data-set, while the strong lensing result refers to case 1 and to case 7 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. For an easier comparison we overplotted some previous recent results. We show in the plot the results obtained through a strong lensing analysis by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R92\">Richard et&#160;al. (2010)</a> (label SL-R09), through a weak and a strong lensing analysis by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R78\">Newman et&#160;al. (2009)</a> (labels WL-N09 and SL-N09, respectively) and in Paper&#160;I through a weak lensing analysis (label WL-Ro09; the results shown here were obtained by adopting a spherical NFW profile; the shear catalogue in this case was derived through the shapelet decomposition technique). The bars show the 1-<i>&#963;</i> errors. (<i>Top right panel</i>) Projected 2D mass profiles obtained with the X-ray (red solid line) and with the strong lensing analyses when modelling the BCG as a dPIE (green dashed line) or a S&#233;rsic halo (blue dashed line). The vertical lines mark the spatial range of the strong lensing (black dotted line) and X-ray (red solid line) constraints. The X-ray (strong lensing) profile was derived by measuring the enclosed mass in cylinders centred on the X-ray emission centroid [BCG]. The distance between the X-ray centroid and the BCG centre is &#160;&#8771;&#160;1&#160;&#177;&#160;1.5&#160;arcsec. The mass map derived from the strong lensing analysis was extrapolated up to a radius of 200 arcsec from the mass measurements obtained in the central regions. The statistical errors on the strong lensing profiles were determined computing the standard deviation from 300 mass map realizations. As a comparison, we report the estimates of the projected total mass within 250 kpc obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R92\">Richard et&#160;al. (2010)</a> through a strong lensing analysis (label SL-R09, marked with a filled black circle) and through an X-ray analysis by <a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R96\">Sanderson et&#160;al. (2009a)</a> (label X-ray-S09, marked with a filled orange square). (<i>Bottom right panel</i>) Ratios between the X-ray and the strong lensing projected mass estimates; the strong lensing estimates were obtained by modelling the BCG through a dPIE (red solid line) or a S&#233;rsic (blue dotted line) profile. </p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>While this possible source of systematic errors in the strong lensing mass estimate was already observed in other studies, the dependence of the derived cluster total mass on the assumed BCG mass profile is a new evidence in the strong lensing analysis of real galaxy clusters, which was already observed through the analysis of simulated galaxy clusters by <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R67\">Meneghetti et&#160;al. (2010)</a>. A similar but less significant effect is related to the scaling of the <i>ML</i> relation, which is assumed to derive the cluster galaxy masses, as is evident by comparing case 2 and case 3 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. </p>\n<p>Another explanation of the X-ray/strong lensing mass mismatch for Abell&#160;611 could be an oblate-like cluster geometry: as demonstrated in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R34\">Gavazzi (2005)</a> (see also <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R73\">Morandi et&#160;al. 2011</a>, <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R72\">2010</a>; <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R21\">Corless et&#160;al. 2009</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R67\">Meneghetti et&#160;al. 2010</a>), the orientation of the halo along the plane of the sky would cause the lensing mass to under-estimate the true one. On the contrary, the X-ray derived masses are the most stable against possible projection effects because of the cluster asphericity (see again <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R34\">Gavazzi 2005</a>). </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S20\"></a>5. Comparison with previous studies</h2>\n<p>A combined analysis of X-ray data and of Sunyaev-Zel&#8217;dovich effect measurements was performed by <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R23\">De Filippis et&#160;al. (2005)</a> to recover the three-dimensional potential distribution for a sample of 25 massive clusters. They estimated that the elongation of Abell&#160;611 along the line of sight is <i>e</i><sub>los</sub>&#160;&#8771;&#160;&#160;&#160;1.05&#160;&#177;&#160;0.37, while its maximum axial ratio is &#160;&#8771;&#160;1.19&#160;&#177;&#160;0.27, so neither an oblate nor a prolate orientation of Abell&#160;611 can be excluded. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R71\">Morandi et&#160;al. (2007)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R70\">Morandi &amp; Ettori (2007)</a> analysed <i>Chandra </i>X-ray data for a sample of 24 X-ray luminous clusters to derive the scaling relations between their X-ray properties and the Sunyaev-Zel&#8217;dovich effect measurements (in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R71\">Morandi et&#160;al. 2007</a>) and the profiles and the scaling properties of their gas entropy (in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R70\">Morandi &amp; Ettori 2007</a>). They analysed the same <i>Chandra </i>observation of Abell&#160;611 as we (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T1\">1</a> for more details on the <i>Chandra </i>dataset) by adopting a technique similar to the method followed here. Their estimate of the total mass of Abell&#160;611 is <i>M</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(5.18&#160;&#177;&#160;2.15)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> at the radius <i>R</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(1.1&#160;&#177;&#160;0.2)&#160;Mpc which agrees very well with our X-ray result of <i>M</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(6.77&#160;&#177;&#160;0.84)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> at the radius <i>R</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(1.2&#160;&#177;&#160;0.1)&#160;Mpc. </p>\n<p>A very recent re-analysis of the <i>Chandra </i>data for Abell&#160;611 is presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R96\">Sanderson et&#160;al. (2009a)</a> (see also <a name=\"InR95\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R95\">Sanderson &amp; Ponman 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R97\">Sanderson et&#160;al. 2009b</a>). The mass estimate for Abell&#160;611 at <i>R</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(1.3&#160;&#177;&#160;0.1) Mpc derived in their work is <i>M</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(9.23&#160;&#177;&#160;2.8)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, which again agrees well with our results. </p>\n<p>An analysis of the weak gravitational lensing effect induced by this cluster was performed by <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R22\">Dahle (2006)</a> through observations in the <i>I </i>and <i>V </i>bands obtained with the University of Hawaii Telescope and the Nordic Optical Telescope. Assuming an NFW profile to model the radial density distribution and a concentration parameter as predicted by <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R19\">Bullock et&#160;al. (2001)</a>, they obtained a mass value of <i>M</i><sub>180</sub>&#160;=&#160;(5.21&#160;&#177;&#160;3.47)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> within <i>R</i><sub>180</sub>. The same data were reanalysed by <a name=\"InR81\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R81\">Pedersen &amp; Dahle (2007)</a>, who derived an estimate of <i>M</i><sub>500</sub>&#160;=&#160;(3.83&#160;&#177;&#160;2.89)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. </p>\n<p>A very recent study of the weak lensing effect in Abell&#160;611 is presented in Paper&#160;I. This work takes advantage of the imaging data obtained through the Large Binocular Camera (LBC) mounted at the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT), which were presented in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S8\">3</a>. Their weak lensing analysis benefits by the wide field of view of the LBC (&#160;&#8771;&#160;23&#160;&#160;arcmin&#160;&#215;&#160;25&#160;&#160;arcmin) and two different methods of extracting the shear signal, the well known KSB approach (<a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R46\">Kaiser et&#160;al. 1995</a>) and the shapelet decomposition technique, proposed more recently by <a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R88\">Refregier (2003); </a><a name=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R89\">Refregier &amp; Bacon (2003)</a> and <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R61\">Massey &amp; Refregier (2005)</a>. Their model-indepent estimates of the total projected mass within a radius of &#160;&#8771;&#160;1.5 Mpc are <i>M</i><sub>projec,&#160;&#8201;&#160;WL,&#160;&#8201;&#160;1</sub>&#160;=&#160;(7.7&#160;&#177;&#160;3.3)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> and <i>M</i><sub>projec,&#160;&#8201;&#160;WL,&#160;&#8201;&#160;2</sub>&#160;=&#160;(8.4&#160;&#177;&#160;3.8)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> when adopting the KSB or the shapelet method, respectively. These results agree very well with our X-ray mass estimate, i.e. <i>M</i><sub>projec,&#160;&#8201;&#160;X&#160;-&#160;ray</sub>&#160;=&#160;&#160;[9.8&#160;&#177;&#160;1.4]&#160;&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> at the radius <i>R</i>&#160;&#8771;&#160;1.5&#160;Mpc, while our strong lensing mass estimate is lower (see the discussion in the previous section and the right panel of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F13\">13</a>). </p>\n<p>They also derived a model-dependent estimate by assuming that the total mass profile of the cluster can be parameterised through the NFW profile. The best-fitting results were a total cluster mass of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq362.png\"></span>, at the radius <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq363.png\"></span>&#160;Mpc, and a concentration parameter of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq364.png\"></span> when adopting the KSB (Shapelets) approach. </p>\n<p>For an easier comparison, the best-fitting values of the cluster-scale NFW profile derived in the former case are overplotted in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F13\">13</a>. These results seems to agree better with our X-ray mass results as regards the strong lensing estimates. </p>\n<p>Recently, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R92\">Richard et&#160;al. (2010)</a> (R09) published the results of a strong lensing analysis performed on a subsample of 10 massive clusters extracted from the Local Cluster Substructure Survey (LoCuSS), which included Abell&#160;611. </p>\n<p>Another study dedicated to the analysis of the matter distribution in Abell&#160;611 was recently performed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R78\">Newman et&#160;al. (2009)</a> (N09). They reconstructed the cluster mass distribution by combining weak and strong lensing analyses and dynamical data, taking advantage of Subaru, HST, and Keck data, respectively. The strong lensing parametric analyses of both R09 and N09 were performed with the software <i>Lenstool</i>. We overplotted their results for an NFW profile fit in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F13\">13</a>. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R92\">Richard et&#160;al. (2010)</a> considered as constraints to the lens optimisation both the confirmed (labelled A, B, and C in our notation) and the candidate (labelled D) systems (as in the case&#160;5 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>), but including only one set of conjugated knots for the tangential arc (system A in our notation). Their results are consistent with our strong lensing findings, which are obtained modelling the BCG as a dPIE halo within the 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence range, while a larger mismatch is found with our X-ray results and with the strong lensing results in case&#160;7. The discussion in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S19\">4</a> could likely also be applied to a comparison between the strong lensing results of R09 and the X-ray and weak lensing mass estimates of Abell&#160;611. </p>\n<p>Regarding the results obtained by N09 through the fit of a NFW profile to the strong lensing data, their best-fitting values show an even higher discrepancy with our mass results: for example, they derive a concentration parameter significantly higher than the concentration derived from both our X-ray and our strong lensing analyses. An extensive comparison of our results with the findings of R09 and N09 is beyond the aims of this comparative section. One of the differences in the strong lensing modelling that could have an impact on the final results is the number of adopted constraints, because N09 included only the brightest knots of the systems A, B, and D in their strong lensing analysis. It could be that using as input all or most of the constraints that can be derived from the morphology of the lensed images in Abell&#160;611 could decrease the discrepancy between their results and ours. Indeed, it is apparent that their results follow the degeneracies expected in the strong lensing parameter estimates between the cluster halo parameters and the central stellar component, which can be reduced by forcing the best-fitting lens model to reproduce realistic reconstructions of the observed lensed images. Moreover, it is interesting that the SL best-fit parameters reported in N09 agree better with the results we obtained by linking all the perturber cluster galaxies to the same relation (case&#160;4 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). This evidence reinforces our conclusions about the significant impact that the modelling of the galactic component can have in the strong lensing analysis of Abell&#160;611, and it could suggest that adopting the same scaling relation for the cluster galaxies in this case could be inadequate. </p>\n<p>The weak lensing results of N09, instead, agree within the 3<i>&#963;</i> errors with both our strong lensing and X-ray mass estimates. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S21\"></a>6. Conclusions and discussion</h2>\n<p>We presented new mass estimates for the relaxed cluster Abell&#160;611, derived through the analysis of the cluster X-ray emission and of its exceptional strong lensing system. We performed a non-parametric reconstruction of the gas density and temperature profile through the only <i>Chandra </i>observation available to date. The cluster total mass was then estimated adopting the NFW profile as mass functional, under the assumptions of spherical symmetry and of hydrostatic equilibrium. </p>\n<p>Our X-ray estimates of the cluster total mass are <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;9.32&#160;&#177;&#160;1.39&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> and <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;11.11&#160;&#177;&#160;2.06&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> when deriving the X-ray background through the blank-field observations or through the source dataset, respectively, thus demonstrating the effect of the X-ray background treatment on the cluster mass estimate. The inclusion of the metallicity as free parameter in the spectral fitting was found to have a negligible impact on the cluster mass results. </p>\n<p>We reconstructed the projected mass distribution in the central region of Abell&#160;611 through a parametric analysis of its remarkable strong lensing system, using the publicly available software <i>Lenstool</i>. We used as constraints to the lens optimisation a detailed system of conjugated lensed images, indentifying 14 sets of knots in three different lensed systems. We adopted an elliptical NFW profile to parametrise the smooth cluster halo; moreover we added the small-scale perturbers constituted by the cluster galaxies by adopting a scaling relation that links their total mass to their luminosity. We ran several tests to verify if and how the strong lensing cluster mass estimate is dependent on the modelling of the galactic component, in particular on the distribution of the BCG baryonic mass component. </p>\n<p>We found that the extrapolated strong lensing mass for Abell&#160;611 is</p>\n<p><ul class=\"dash\">\n          <li>\n            <p> moderately sensitive to the mass modelling of the galaxy-scaleperturbers that\n              determine the peculiar characteristics of thestrong lensing system in Abell&#160;611;\n              indeed, weobtained that the different cluster galaxy parametrisations caninduce a\n              scatter of up to 10% on the total mass estimate (when extrapolating the SL mass up to\n                <i>R</i><sub>200</sub>) with respect to the mean value (comparing Cases 1\n              to 6 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>); </p>\n          </li>\n          <li>\n            <p> more significantly affected by the inferred BCG baryonic mass budget (because of the\n              degeneracy between the cluster halo mass and the BCG baryonic mass) and by the assumed\n              mass profile for the BCG baryonic halo. The deviation of the extrapolated total mass\n              with respect to the mean value can be as high as &#160;&#160;&#160;40% when adopting different mass\n              profiles for the BCG stellar mass distribution (comparing cases&#160;1 to 7 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). </p>\n          </li>\n        </ul>For example, from the strong lensing analysis we derived for Abell&#160;611 the mass estimates of <i>M</i><sub>200,&#160;&#8201;&#160;dPIE</sub>&#160;=&#160;4.68&#160;&#177;&#160;0.31&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup>&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, when modelling the BCG with a dPIE model, and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq370.png\"></span>, when assuming the S&#233;rsic profile as the BCG mass functional. The baryonic BCG mass inferred in both cases is similar, and both estimates are dependent on the optimisation limits imposed to the BCG mass parameters. </p>\n<p>Our X-ray and strong lensing mass estimates agree well in the central regions, where the total projected mass can actually be constrained through the strong lensing analysis, while we find a significant difference between the X-ray mass and the extrapolated SL mass in the cluster outer region. This result suggests that the observed mismatch between the X-ray and the strong lensing mass could be caused by the incorrect estimate of the BCG stellar mass content or of the total mass of cluster galaxies in the central regions, because gravitational lensing alone cannot separate the mass of the different lens components. </p>\n<p>However, even with these caveats in the interpretation of the results, the X-ray and strong lensing mass estimates for Abell&#160;611 in the most opportune cases are consistent within the 3<i>&#963;</i> error range. These findings support the hypothesis that taking into account the possible sources of errors and deepening our knowledge of the current limitations of the X-ray and strong lensing analyses, both techniques return robust results. Their reliability can be increased even more by extending the detailed analysis of possible systematic biases affecting the mass estimates to other appropriate objects, i.e. massive, relaxed galaxy clusters like Abell&#160;611. </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> See the CIAO analysis guides for the data reduction: <a href=\"http://cxc.harvard.edu/ciao/guides/\" target=\"_blank\">cxc.harvard.edu/ciao/guides/</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN3\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> For a complete discussion on this topic, see <a href=\"http://cxc.harvard.edu/cal/Acis/Cal_prods/vfbkgrnd/index.html\" target=\"_blank\">cxc.harvard.edu/cal/Acis/Cal_prods/vfbkgrnd/index.html</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN4\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The url of the MAST is archive.stsci.edu.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN5\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The software <i>SExtractor</i>, <i>Scamp </i>and <i>Swarp </i>can be found at the url: <a href=\"http://astromatic.iap.fr/software/sextractor\" target=\"_blank\">astromatic.iap.fr/software/sextractor</a>, <a href=\"http://astromatic.iap.fr/software/scamp%20and%20astromatic.iap.fr/software/swarp\" target=\"_blank\">astromatic.iap.fr/software/scamp and astromatic.iap.fr/software/swarp</a>, respectively.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN6\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> See the Large Binocular Camera website hosted by the OAR-Osservatorio Astronomico di Roma: lbc.mporzio.astro.it .</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The <i>Lenstool </i>software package is available at <a href=\"http://www.oamp.fr/cosmology/lenstool\" target=\"_blank\">www.oamp.fr/cosmology/lenstool</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The <i>GALFIT </i>software is publicly available at the url <a href=\"http://users.obs.carnegiescience.edu/peng/work/galfit/galfit.html\" target=\"_blank\">users.obs.carnegiescience.edu/peng/work/galfit/galfit.html</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN9\"></a><sup>8</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The TinyTim software is available at the url <a href=\"http://www.stsci.edu/software/tinytim/tinytim.html\" target=\"_blank\">www.stsci.edu/software/tinytim/tinytim.html</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN10\"></a><sup>9</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The cut radius corresponds to the 3-D half mass radius for a null core radius (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R28\">El&#237;asd&#243;ttir et&#160;al. 2007</a>).</p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>These results are based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <i>Hubble </i>Space telescope, with the <i>Chandra </i>X-ray Observatory and with the Large Binocular Telescope. We thank the anonymous referee for carefully reading the article, and for useful comments and suggestions that improved the presentation of our results. We thank Jean Paul Kneib and the <i>Lenstool </i>developers for making their lensing software public.   </ol>\n    </div>\n\n    \n      <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix A:  Multiple-image systems</h2>\n<p>We list in this Appendix the coordinates of the input multiple image systems that we used to constrain the lens model for Abell&#160;611. The position of the knots for the image systems corresponding to source A and B are shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F14\">A.1</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F14\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;A.1</span></a>\n              <p>Details of the images used as constraints for the lens optimisation corresponding to the sources A and B (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">A.1</a>). The first three panels on the left show the location of the knots selected along the tangential arc, while the last four panels on the right show the conjugate knots identified in the quintuplet system. All panels were selected in the galaxy-subtracted image, obtained through the two-dimensional fitting algorithm <i>GALFIT </i>(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R83\">Peng et&#160;al. 2002</a>). The images were smoothed with a 2&#160;pixel <i>FWHM </i>Gaussian filter for a better visualisation.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"T8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;A.1</span></a>\n              <p>Coordinates of the multiple images used as constraints in the lens model optimisation.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix B:  Comparison between predicted image configurations</h2>\n<p>In this Appendix we compare the observed strong lensing system of Abell&#160;611 to the lensed images predicted by our best-fit models. The top left panel shows the ACS/HST image of Abell&#160;611 (filter <i>F</i>606<i>W</i>), in which the galaxies were subtracted through the software <i>Galfit</i>. The last seven panels show the images predicted by our best-fitting lens models, corresponding to the cases listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F15\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;B.1</span></a>\n              <p>Comparison between the images predicted by our best-fit models and the observed lensed features. (<i>Top left panel</i>) Galaxy-subtracted ACS/HST image of Abell&#160;611. The identified (A,B,C) and candidate (D) lensed systems are marked in green, magenta, cyan, and red. (<i>Top middle, top right, middle and bottom panels</i>) The predicted critical (caustic) lines are overlaid in red (blue) on the images predicted by the best-fit models listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. They refer to a source plane at redshift <i>z</i><sub><i>A</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.908. The predicted sources are drawn in the last seven panels with the same colour as the corresponding image system in the top left panel. The conjugated knots used as constraints are shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a>, whereas their coordinates are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">A.1</a>. The field dimensions of the panels are &#160;&#8771;&#160;&#160;[35.2&#160;&#215;&#160;35.1]&#160;&#160;arcsec; all fields are WCS-aligned. The flux scale is the same in the last seven panels.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n    \n  <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div
