href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;1</span></a>\n            <p>(<i>Left panel</i>) F606W ACS/HST image of the cluster Abell&#160;611 (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T3\">3</a> for the observation summary). The X-ray isophotes derived from the <i>Chandra </i>image (shown in the middle panel) are overlaid in white. The green cross indicates the X-ray centroid. (<i>Middle panel</i>) The <i>Chandra </i>X-ray image of Abell&#160;611 in the energy range [0.25&#8211;7.0]&#160;keV. The image was smoothed with a 3&#160;pixel <i>FWHM </i>Gaussian filter, and is not exposure-corrected. The contours derived from the HST image (shown in the <i>left panel</i>) are overlaid in white to facilitate the comparison between the images. Here again the green cross marks the X-ray centroid. (<i>Right panel</i>) Pseudo-colour composite image of Abell&#160;611, obtained combining <i>r</i> and <i>g</i>-SLOAN images, taken with the Large Binocular Camera mounted at LBT. The three panels are WCS-aligned; the size of the field of view is &#160;&#8771;&#160;&#160;[1.6&#160;&#215;&#160;1.8]&#160;&#160;arcmin.</p>\n          </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;2</span></a>\n              <p>(<i>Top left panel</i>) Deprojected gas density profile. The red circles indicate the values determined by the normalisation of the thermal spectra, while diamonds represent the values obtained combining both spectral and surface brightness measurements: the dashed line shows the best-fit profile. (<i>Bottom left panel</i>) ICM temperature profile. The figure shows the projected temperature values, directly inferred from the spectral analysis (red filled circles) and the deprojected values, which were rebinned to the same binning of the spectral profile (diamonds). The dashed line shows the deprojected best-fit profile. (<i>Right panel</i>) The projected (black empty diamonds) and deprojected (red filled circles) metallicity profile for Abell&#160;611 inferred from the X-ray analysis. The dotted line represents the mean metallicity value <i>Z</i>&#160;=&#160;(0.45&#160;&#177;&#160;0.1)&#160;&#160;<i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, as determined through the fit of the spectrum extracted in the area with radius <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;2.9&#160;arcmin, i.e. the cluster area covered by our spectral analysis. The grey region indicates the 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence level.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;3</span></a>\n              <p>(<i>Left panel</i>) Mass profiles for Abell&#160;611 as determined through the X-ray analysis. The black solid line and the red dashed line indicate the total mass and the gas mass profile, respectively. (<i>Right panel</i>) Confidence levels determined through the X-ray analysis for the NFW profile parameters <i>r</i><sub>s</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>. The red circle indicates the best-fit values, while the contours represent the 1<i>&#963;,</i>2<i>&#963;</i>, and 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;4</span></a>\n              <p>Comparison between the temperature profile determined by estimating the X-ray background through the blank-sky dataset (red dashed line) or using a local background component (black solid line).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;5</span></a>\n              <p>Overview of the strong lensing system of Abell&#160;611. The knots that we used as constraints are marked as red crosses on the <i>F</i>606<i>W</i> ACS/HST image; enlarged images are shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F14\">A.1</a>. The magenta crosses indicate the perturber galaxies that were optimised singularly (see Case 6 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The blue crosses correspond to a likely lensed system, identified by R09, which is not yet confirmed spectroscopically. We discuss our selection of the input images and its effect on the results in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S10\">3.2</a> and Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S18\">3.7</a>. The coordinates of all the systems are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">A.1</a>. The size of the field of view is &#160;&#8771;&#160;50&#160;&#215;&#160;42.5 arcsec; the image was smoothed with a 2&#160;pixel <i>FWHM </i>Gaussian filter (1 pixel = 0.05 arcsec).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;6</span></a>\n                <p>Colour&#8211;magnitude diagram of Abell&#160;611. The black lines define the cluster red-sequence, while the blue filled squares indicate the red sequence galaxies lying within 100 arcsec from the BCG centre, which were included in the lens modelling. The black circle indicates the galaxy located between the lensed images B.1 and C.1 (see Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a>), which was included in the lens modelling for its position; the magnitude estimate derived for this galaxy from the LBT data is contaminated by the flux contribution of the nearby lensed feature (see text for details).</p>\n              </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;7</span></a>\n              <p>(<i>Top Panels</i>) Comparison between the projected mass maps obtained when modelling the BCG with a dPIE profile (<i>left panel</i>, case 1 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>) or with a S&#233;rsic profile (<i>right panel</i>, case 7 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). See Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a> and the text for further details. (<i>Bottom Panels</i>) Comparison between the surface mass density profiles for the BCG halo (<i>left panel</i>) and the NFW cluster scale halo (<i>right panel</i>) derived when modelling the BCG with a dPIE profile (red solid line, case 1) or with a S&#233;rsic profile (green dashed line, case 7).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F7\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;8</span></a>\n              <p>Scatter plots for the NFW parameters <i>r</i><sub>s</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> obtained for some representative cases. The numbering of the cases corresponds to the numbering in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. The red point distribution marks the 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence level for the two parameters. The green stars indicate the best-fit values; the error-bars refer to the 1<i>&#963;</i> statistical uncertainty. We used the same knot systems as inputs and the same priors on the cluster halo mass distribution in all the six cases; the only differences were the modelling and the parameterisation of the cluster galaxies and of the BCG. The probability distribution in case 4 appears squeezed because it crushed on the lower limit for the BCG characteristic central velocity dispersion. The lens model results for the cases shown here are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. </p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F8\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;9</span></a>\n              <p>Scatter plots of cluster-halo parameters (<i>c</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>M</i><sub>tot</sub>) versus parameters of the modelling of either the BCG or the perturber galaxy n.1 (hereafter P1, see text for details). Here we show the posterior probability distributions obtained in a representative case (case 1 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The plotted parameters are: 1.&#160;the NFW concentration parameter <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> versus the BCG fiducial central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,BCG</sub> (<i>top left panel</i>); 2.&#160;the cluster halo mass <i>M</i><sub>tot</sub> versus <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,BCG</sub><i>top right panel</i>); 3.&#160;the NFW concentration parameter <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> versus the fiducial central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,P1</sub> of the galaxy P1 (<i>bottom left panel</i>); 4.&#160; the cluster halo mass <i>M</i><sub>tot</sub> versus <i>&#963;</i><sub>0,P1</sub> (<i>bottom right panel</i>). The contours show the 68%, 95% and 99% confidence levels. The colour code refers to the value of the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> estimator.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F9\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;10</span></a>\n              <p>Median values of the dPIE truncation radius <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub> vs. the characteristic dPIE central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> for the galaxies that perturb the strong lensing system of Abell&#160;611. The red triangles show the results obtained linking the galaxy parameters to the same scaling relation in the lens modelling (Case 4 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>), while the blue stars represent the results obtained optimising the galaxies individually (Case 6 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The grey dashed lines show the iso-density contours. The error bars indicate the 1<i>&#963;</i> uncertainty, while the cyan boxes indicate the 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence region for the results which refer to Case 4.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F10\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;11</span></a>\n              <p>ACS/HST snapshot of a radial-oriented feature, likely a central counter-image corresponding to System B; the BCG is visible [subtracted] in the left [right] panel.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F11\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;12</span></a>\n            <p>Comparison between the ACS/HST <i>F</i>606<i>W</i> observation (<i>left panel</i>), smoothed with a 3 <i>FWHM </i>pixel Gaussian filter for a better visualisation of the faint lensed image C.1 (marked with a white circle), and the reconstructed image systems predicted from the lens models in case 1 ((<i>middle panel</i>): in this case the BCG was modelled as a dPIE potential) and case 7 ((<i>right panel</i>): the BCG was parametrised with a S&#233;rsic profile &#8211; see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>). The white circles in the middle and right panels mark the centre of the predicted counter-images. The black circle in the left panel indicates a candidate counter-image of C.1, indentified with SExtractor. The three images are WCS-aligned; the flux scale of the second and the third panel is the same. </p>\n          </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F12\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;13</span></a>\n            <p>(<i>Left panel</i>) Comparison of the NFW parameter probability distribution obtained with our X-ray and strong lensing analyses. The X-ray and the strong lensing contours show the 3-<i>&#963;</i> confidence level (the strong lensing results were marginalised over the other fit parameters). The X-ray contours were obtained deriving the X-ray background from the blank-sky data-set, while the strong lensing result refers to case 1 and to case 7 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. For an easier comparison we overplotted some previous recent results. We show in the plot the results obtained through a strong lensing analysis by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R92\">Richard et&#160;al. (2010)</a> (label SL-R09), through a weak and a strong lensing analysis by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R78\">Newman et&#160;al. (2009)</a> (labels WL-N09 and SL-N09, respectively) and in Paper&#160;I through a weak lensing analysis (label WL-Ro09; the results shown here were obtained by adopting a spherical NFW profile; the shear catalogue in this case was derived through the shapelet decomposition technique). The bars show the 1-<i>&#963;</i> errors. (<i>Top right panel</i>) Projected 2D mass profiles obtained with the X-ray (red solid line) and with the strong lensing analyses when modelling the BCG as a dPIE (green dashed line) or a S&#233;rsic halo (blue dashed line). The vertical lines mark the spatial range of the strong lensing (black dotted line) and X-ray (red solid line) constraints. The X-ray (strong lensing) profile was derived by measuring the enclosed mass in cylinders centred on the X-ray emission centroid [BCG]. The distance between the X-ray centroid and the BCG centre is &#160;&#8771;&#160;1&#160;&#177;&#160;1.5&#160;arcsec. The mass map derived from the strong lensing analysis was extrapolated up to a radius of 200 arcsec from the mass measurements obtained in the central regions. The statistical errors on the strong lensing profiles were determined computing the standard deviation from 300 mass map realizations. As a comparison, we report the estimates of the projected total mass within 250 kpc obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R92\">Richard et&#160;al. (2010)</a> through a strong lensing analysis (label SL-R09, marked with a filled black circle) and through an X-ray analysis by <a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R96\">Sanderson et&#160;al. (2009a)</a> (label X-ray-S09, marked with a filled orange square). (<i>Bottom right panel</i>) Ratios between the X-ray and the strong lensing projected mass estimates; the strong lensing estimates were obtained by modelling the BCG through a dPIE (red solid line) or a S&#233;rsic (blue dotted line) profile. </p>\n          </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F13\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;A.1</span></a>\n              <p>Details of the images used as constraints for the lens optimisation corresponding to the sources A and B (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">A.1</a>). The first three panels on the left show the location of the knots selected along the tangential arc, while the last four panels on the right show the conjugate knots identified in the quintuplet system. All panels were selected in the galaxy-subtracted image, obtained through the two-dimensional fitting algorithm <i>GALFIT </i>(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R83\">Peng et&#160;al. 2002</a>). The images were smoothed with a 2&#160;pixel <i>FWHM </i>Gaussian filter for a better visualisation.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F14\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;B.1</span></a>\n              <p>Comparison between the images predicted by our best-fit models and the observed lensed features. (<i>Top left panel</i>) Galaxy-subtracted ACS/HST image of Abell&#160;611. The identified (A,B,C) and candidate (D) lensed systems are marked in green, magenta, cyan, and red. (<i>Top middle, top right, middle and bottom panels</i>) The predicted critical (caustic) lines are overlaid in red (blue) on the images predicted by the best-fit models listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T5\">5</a>. They refer to a source plane at redshift <i>z</i><sub><i>A</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.908. The predicted sources are drawn in the last seven panels with the same colour as the corresponding image system in the top left panel. The conjugated knots used as constraints are shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F5\">5</a>, whereas their coordinates are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T8\">A.1</a>. The field dimensions of the panels are &#160;&#8771;&#160;&#160;[35.2&#160;&#215;&#160;35.1]&#160;&#160;arcsec; all fields are WCS-aligned. The flux scale is the same in the last seven panels.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F15\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201014120\" data-edps_ref=\"aa14120-10\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa15400-10/aa15400-10.html\" class=\"back\"><span></span>Previous article</a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa15465-10/aa15465-10.html\" Richard\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Physics, Institute for Computational Cosmology, Durham University, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Abell\u00a0611 - II. X-ray and strong lensing analyses\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2011/03/03\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2011/04/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"528\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A73\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201014120\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2011A%26A...528A..73D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2011/04/aa14120-10.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"X-ray: galaxies: clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: individual Abell 611\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We present the results of our analyses of the X-ray emission and of the strong lensing systems in the galaxy cluster Abell\u00a0611 [&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a00.288]. This cluster is an optimal candidate for a comparison of the mass reconstructions obtained through X-ray and lensing techniques, because of its very relaxed dynamical appearance and its exceptional strong lensing system. We infer the X-ray mass estimate deriving the density and temperature profile of the intra-cluster medium within the radius &lt;i&gt;r&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0\u2243\u00a0700\u00a0kpc through a non-parametric approach, taking advantage of the high spatial resolution of a &lt;i&gt;Chandra &lt;i/&gt;observation. Assuming that the cluster is in hydrostatic equilibrium and adopting a matter density profile, we can recover the total mass distribution of Abell\u00a0611 via the X-ray data. Moreover, we derive the total projected mass in the central regions of Abell\u00a0611 performing a parametric analysis of its strong lensing features through the publicly available analysis software &lt;i&gt;Lenstool&lt;i/&gt;. As a final step we compare the results obtained with both methods. We derive a good agreement between the X-ray and strong lensing total mass estimates in the central regions where the strong lensing constraints are present (i.e. within the radius &lt;i&gt;r&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0\u2243\u00a0100\u00a0kpc), while a marginal disagreement is found between the two mass estimates when extrapolating the strong lensing results in the outer spatial range. We suggest that in this case the X-ray/strong lensing mass disagreement can be explained by an incorrect estimate of the relative contributions of the baryonic component and of the dark matter, caused by the intrinsic degeneracy between the different mass components in the strong lensing analysis. We discuss the effect of some possible systematic errors that influence both mass estimates. We find a slight dependence of the measurements of the X-ray temperatures (and therefore of the X-ray total masses) on the background adopted in the spectral analysis, with total deviations on the value of &lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt; of the order of the 1&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; statistical error. The strong lensing mass results are instead sensitive to the parameterisation of the galactic halo mass in the central regions, in particular to the modelling of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) baryonic component, which induces a significant scatter in the strong lensing mass results.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=S. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div to databases </a></li><li class=\"item-381\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/latex-examples\" >LaTeX examples</a></li><li class=\"item-466\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/information-files\" >Information files</a></li></ul></li><li class=\"item-456\"><a href=\"https://writingstudio.aws.edpsciences.org/login\" target=\"_blank\" >Writing studio</a></li><li class=\"item-459\"><a >News</a></li></ul>\n\n                        </nav>\n                                            \n                      \n<div id=\"system-message-container\">\n</div>\n                      \n\n                      \n                                              <div class=\"flexme flexme-article\">\n                        <div class=\"article-content\">\n                                <div>\r\n    \n<div class=\"special_article green\">Free Access</div>\n    \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n \r\n    <div class=\"summary full\" >\n\t<table>\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\t<tr>\n\t\t<th valign=\"top\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIssue\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t<td width=\"10\"></td>\n\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tA&A\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div><strong>Volume </strong>528, April 2011\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</td>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" ></td></tr>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" class=\"sep_issue\"></td></tr>\n\t</tr>\n\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tArticle Number\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>A73</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tNumber of page(s)\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>19</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Section</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>Cosmology (including clusters of galaxies)</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>DOI</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201014120\">\n\t\t\t\t\thttps://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201014120\n\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Published online</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t03 March 2011\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t</table>\n</div>\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#abs\">Abstract</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S1\">1. Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S2\">2. X-ray analysis</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S8\">3. Strong lensing analysis</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S19\" title=\"Comparison between X-ray and strong lensing results\">4. Comparison between ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S20\" title=\"Comparison with previous studies\">5. Comparison with ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S21\">6. Conclusions and discussion</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#ack\">Acknowledgments</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#app\">Appendix A:</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 528, A73 (2011)<h2 class=\"title\">Abell&#160;611</h2>\n<h3 class=\"subtitle\">II. X-ray and strong lensing analyses</h3>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa14120-10-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=1\" class=\"author\">A. Donnarumma</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,2</sup><sup>,3</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=2\" class=\"author author-orcid\">S. Ettori</span><sup>2</sup><sup>,3</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">M. Meneghetti</span><sup>2</sup><sup>,3</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-4\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=4\" class=\"author\">R. Gavazzi</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,5</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">B. Fort</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,5</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">L. Moscardini</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,3</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-7\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=7\" class=\"author\">A. Romano</span><sup>6</sup><sup>,7</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-8\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=8\" class=\"author\">L. Fu</span><sup>8</sup><sup>,10</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-9\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=9\" class=\"author\">F. Giordano</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">M. Radovich</span><sup>8</sup><sup>,9</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">R. Maoli</span><sup>6</sup>, <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">R. Scaramella</span><sup>7</sup> and <span id=\"aa14120-10-author-13\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201014120&amp;n=13\" class=\"author\">J. Richard</span><sup>11</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\"><sup>1</sup>  Dipartimento di AstronomiaUniversit&#224;\n              di Bologna,  via Ranzani\n              1,  40127   Bologna,  Italy <br>\n          e-mail:  annamaria.donnarumm2@unibo.it\n          <br><sup>2</sup> INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di\n              Bologna, via Ranzani 1,  40127 \n             Bologna,\n             Italy \n        <br><sup>3</sup> INFN, Sezione di Bologna, viale Berti\n              Pichat 6/2,  40127 \n             Bologna,\n             Italy \n        <br><sup>4</sup> Institut d'Astrophysique de Paris, CNRS UMR 7095,  98bis Bd Arago,  75014   Paris,  France <br><sup>5</sup> UPMC Universit&#233; Paris 06, UMR 7095,  75014   Paris,  France <br><sup>6</sup> Dipartimento di Fisica, Universit&#224; La\n              Sapienza, Piazzale\n              A.Moro \n             00185 \n             Roma,\n             Italy \n        <br><sup>7</sup>  INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di\n          Roma, via Frascati 33, 00044 Monte Porzio Catone,  Roma,  Italy <br><sup>8</sup> INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di\n              Napoli, via Moiariello 16,  80131 \n             Napoli,\n             Italy \n        <br><sup>9</sup>  INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di\n        Padova,  vicolo dell&#8217;Osservatorio 5,  35122 \n             Padova,\n             Italy \n        <br><sup>10</sup> Key Lab for Astrophysics, Shanghai\n              Normal University, 100 Guilin Road,\n              200234 \n             Shanghai,  PR\n            China \n        <br><sup>11</sup> Department of Physics, Institute\n              for Computational Cosmology, Durham University,  South Road,  Durham \n             DH1 3LE,\n             UK \n        <br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>22 January 2010<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>17 October 2010</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n        <p>  We present the results of our analyses of the X-ray emission and of the strong lensing systems in the galaxy cluster Abell&#160;611 [<i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.288]. This cluster is an optimal candidate for a comparison of the mass reconstructions obtained through X-ray and lensing techniques, because of its very relaxed dynamical appearance and its exceptional strong lensing system. We infer the X-ray mass estimate deriving the density and temperature profile of the intra-cluster medium within the radius <i>r</i>&#160;&#8771;&#160;700&#160;kpc through a non-parametric approach, taking advantage of the high spatial resolution of a <i>Chandra </i>observation. Assuming that the cluster is in hydrostatic equilibrium and adopting a matter density profile, we can recover the total mass distribution of Abell&#160;611 via the X-ray data. Moreover, we derive the total projected mass in the central regions of Abell&#160;611 performing a parametric analysis of its strong lensing features through the publicly available analysis software <i>Lenstool</i>. As a final step we compare the results obtained with both methods. We derive a good agreement between the X-ray and strong lensing total mass estimates in the central regions where the strong lensing constraints are present (i.e. within the radius <i>r</i>&#160;&#8771;&#160;100&#160;kpc), while a marginal disagreement is found between the two mass estimates when extrapolating the strong lensing results in the outer spatial range. We suggest that in this case the X-ray/strong lensing mass disagreement can be explained by an incorrect estimate of the relative contributions of the baryonic component and of the dark matter, caused by the intrinsic degeneracy between the different mass components in the strong lensing analysis. We discuss the effect of some possible systematic errors that influence both mass estimates. We find a slight dependence of the measurements of the X-ray temperatures (and therefore of the X-ray total masses) on the background adopted in the spectral analysis, with total deviations on the value of <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> of the order of the 1<i>&#963;</i> statistical error. The strong lensing mass results are instead sensitive to the parameterisation of the galactic halo mass in the central regions, in particular to the modelling of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) baryonic component, which induces a significant scatter in the strong lensing mass results. </p>\n      <div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>gravitational lensing: strong / X-ray: galaxies: clusters / galaxies: clusters: general / galaxies: clusters: individual Abell 611</p></div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO, 2011</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>Testing the accuracy of the several approaches used to estimate the mass of galaxy clusters is necessary to assess the reliability of methods involving clusters as cosmological probes. For example, the comparison of the cluster baryon fractions f<sub>b</sub> to the cosmic baryon fraction can provide a direct constraint on the mean mass density of the Universe, &#937;<sub>M</sub> (<a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R32\">Ettori et&#160;al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R2\">Allen et&#160;al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R31\">Ettori et&#160;al. 2003</a>), while the evolution of the cluster mass function can tightly constrain &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> and the dark energy equation-of-state parameter <i>w</i> (<a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R104\">Vikhlinin et&#160;al. 2009</a>). </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;1</span></a>\n            <p>(<i>Left panel</i>) F606W ACS/HST image of the cluster Abell&#160;611 (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T3\">3</a> for the observation summary). The X-ray isophotes derived from the <i>Chandra </i>image (shown in the middle panel) are overlaid in white. The green cross indicates the X-ray centroid. (<i>Middle panel</i>) The <i>Chandra </i>X-ray image of Abell&#160;611 in the energy range [0.25&#8211;7.0]&#160;keV. The image was smoothed with a 3&#160;pixel <i>FWHM </i>Gaussian filter, and is not exposure-corrected. The contours derived from the HST image (shown in the <i>left panel</i>) are overlaid in white to facilitate the comparison between the images. Here again the green cross marks the X-ray centroid. (<i>Right panel</i>) Pseudo-colour composite image of Abell&#160;611, obtained combining <i>r</i> and <i>g</i>-SLOAN images, taken with the Large Binocular Camera mounted at LBT. The three panels are WCS-aligned; the size of the field of view is &#160;&#8771;&#160;&#160;[1.6&#160;&#215;&#160;1.8]&#160;&#160;arcmin.</p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>Cluster mass profiles can be probed through several independent techniques, relying on different physical mechanisms and requiring different assumptions. The comparison of results obtained with different methods and the (dis)agreement between them provide a useful check, and can give additional insights on the inner structure of clusters. For example, cluster masses can be estimated through the projected phase-space distribution and velocity dispersion of cluster galaxies (<a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R13\">Biviano &amp; Poggianti 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R25\">Diaferio et&#160;al. 2005</a>); the dynamical studies, however, are affected by the strong degeneracy between the mass density profile and the velocity dispersion anisotropy profile, and thus require strong assumptions on the form of the velocity dispersion tensor. </p>\n<p>Measurements of the Sunyaev-Zel&#8217;dovich effect (hereafter SZE;  <a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R101\">Sunyaev &amp; Zel&#8217;dovich 1972</a>) towards galaxy clusters yield a direct measurement of the pressure distribution of the cluster gas: the total gravitational mass can thus be determined combining this information with the intra-cluster medium (hereafter ICM) temperature, estimated for example through the X-ray spectral analysis (<a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R38\">Grego et&#160;al. 2001</a>). Because it is independent of the cluster redshift, the SZE can be an extremely powerful tool to investigate the mass of high-redshift clusters (<a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R42\">Hincks et&#160;al. 2009</a>), but accurate measurements of the SZE are still a challenge because of intrinsic limitations and systematic biases (faint signal extending over a large angular size and subject to several sources of contamination). </p>\n<p>So far, the analysis of the cluster X-ray emission and of the gravitational lensing effect are among the most promising techniques to estimate galaxy cluster masses. </p>\n<p>The X-ray mass estimate is less biased compared with lensing-derived masses by projection effects, because the X-ray emission is traced by the square of the gas density (<a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R34\">Gavazzi 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR107\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R107\">Wu 2000</a>). However, X-ray measurements of cluster masses imply the assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium of the ICM with the dark matter potential and of spherical symmetry of the cluster mass distribution. Hence the total mass profile can be inferred from the radial profiles of gas temperature and density. </p>\n<p>On the other hand, the gravitational lensing effect allows for the determination of the projected surface mass density of the lens, regardless of its dynamical state or the nature of the intervening matter. This effect is determined by all massive structures along the line of sight, so lensing mass measurements are subject to foreground and background contaminations. Moreover, the lensing effect is sensitive to features of the mass distribution such as its ellipticity and asymmetry and to the presence of substructures (<a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R65\">Meneghetti et&#160;al. 2007a</a>). </p>\n<p>The combination of X-ray and lensing results could verify and strengthen the findings on the cluster physics and masses (see for example <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R1\">Allen 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R29\">Ettori &amp; Lombardi 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R16\">Brada&#269; et&#160;al. 2008</a>); but so far several works in literature claimed a significant disagreement between strong lensing and X-ray mass estimates, (<a name=\"InR108\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R108\">Wu &amp; Fang 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR99\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R99\">Smail et&#160;al. 1997</a>; <a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R80\">Ota et&#160;al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR105\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R105\">Voigt &amp; Fabian 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R37\">Gitti et&#160;al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R41\">Halkola et&#160;al. 2008</a>) which would prevent any joint analysis. Many convincing explanations, even if not conclusive, have been suggested. </p>\n<p>It is therefore clear that a comparison between independent mass estimates for galaxy clusters can provide a vital check of the assumptions adopted in the cluster analysis, and will possibly give us additional insights into the underlying physics of these objects. In particular, the comparison between lensing and X-ray mass in galaxy clusters is also directly related to the cosmological parameters, since their ratio depends on the cosmic density parameter, &#937;<sub>M</sub>, and the cosmological constant, &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub>, for their different dependence on the angular diameter distances, which are smaller in an &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> dominated universe, as pointed out by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R107\">Wu (2000)</a>. </p>\n<p>Targets for a comparative analysis should be relaxed, unperturbed objects to avoid biases deriving from the incorrect assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium (X-ray analysis) or from the contamination of secondary mass clumps or unresolved substructures (lensing analysis). </p>\n<p>An ideal candidate for this kind of analysis is Abell&#160;611. It is a rich, cool-core cluster at <i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.288 (<a name=\"InR100\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R100\">Struble &amp; Rood 1999</a>); its X-ray emission peak is well centred on the Brightest Cluster Galaxy (hereafter BCG; see left and central panels of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F1\">1</a>), and the X-ray isophotes appear quite regular, with a low degree of ellipticity. These characteristics are generally considered good indicators of a relaxed dynamical state. Relaxed objects are quite rare at this redshift, so a detailed study of the properties of Abell&#160;611 is even more appealing. </p>\n<p>In this work we will focus on the comparison between the X-ray and strong lensing mass estimates. A weak lensing analysis of large field of view data, obtained with the Large Binocular Camera (LBC) mounted at the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT), is presented in <a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R93\">Romano et&#160;al. (2010)</a> (hereafter Paper&#160;I). Here we present new X-ray and strong lensing mass estimates, based on a non-parametric reconstruction of gas density and temperature profiles obtained through the analysis of a <i>Chandra </i>observation, and on a strong lensing reconstruction respectively, which was performed with the <i>Lenstool </i>analysis software (<a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R49\">Kneib et&#160;al. 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R44\">Jullo et&#160;al. 2007</a>). </p>\n<p>This paper is organised as follows. In Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S2\">2</a> we will introduce our X-ray analysis, focusing on the data reduction and on the method applied to recover the total and gas mass profiles, and discuss some possible systematic errors associated with the X-ray analysis. The strong lensing analysis is presented in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S8\">3</a>, where we will briefly discuss our main findings. We will compare the X-ray and strong lensing results in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S19\">4</a>: a comparison with previous analyses can be found in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S20\">5</a>. Finally, we will summarise our results and draw our conclusions in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S21\">6</a>.   Throughout this work we will assume a flat &#923;CDM cosmology: the matter density parameter will have the value &#937;<sub>m</sub>&#160;=&#160;0.3, the cosmological constant density parameter &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub>&#160;=&#160;0.7, and the Hubble constant will be <i>H</i><sub>0</sub>&#160;=&#160;70&#160;&#160;km&#160;&#160;s<sup>-1</sup>&#160;&#8201;&#160;Mpc<sup>-1</sup>. At the cluster redshift and for the assumed cosmological parameters, 1 arcsec is equivalent to 4.329 kpc. Unless otherwise stated, all uncertainties are referred to a 68% confidence level. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. X-ray analysis</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. X-ray data reduction</h3>\n<p>The X-ray analysis of Abell&#160;611 returns several indicators of a relaxed dynamical state, such as the absence of substructures in the X-ray emission (which appears isotropic over elliptical isophotes), a well-defined cool-core, and a smooth surface brightness profile. The X-ray emission is centred on the BCG: the distance between the X-ray centroid and the BCG centre is &#160;&#8771;&#160;1&#160;arcsec (the uncertainty on this measure is comparable to the smoothing scale applied to the X-ray image to determine the centroid, i.e. 3&#160;pixels &#160;&#8771;&#160;1.5&#160;arcsec). Moreover, Abell&#160;611 appears to be a radio-quiet cluster, because the Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) Radio Halo Survey (<a name=\"InR102\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R102\">Venturi et&#160;al. 2007</a>, <a name=\"InR103\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R103\">2008</a>,see Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S20\">5</a>) failed to detect any extended radio emission associated with this cluster. Since giant radio halos are the most relevant examples of non-thermal activity in galaxy clusters (<a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R18\">Brunetti et&#160;al. 2009</a>), the absence of a radio halo supports the hypothesis of thermal pressure support, connected to the hydrostatic equilibrium assumption required in the X-ray analysis. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;1</span></a>\n              <p>Observation summary of the <i>Chandra </i>exposure used for the X-ray analysis.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>This cluster can therefore be considered an ideal candidate to highlight any issue with the current analysis techniques: it fullfills the assumptions of thermal pressure support and of spherical symmetry, so it is unlikely that potential biases in the results are related to the limiting assumptions underlying the X-ray analysis. We performed our X-ray analysis on the only <i>Chandra </i>data set available, retrieved from the public archive (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T1\">1</a> for observation log). We reduced the data using the <i>CIAO </i>data analysis package &#8211; version 4.0 &#8211; and the calibration database CALDB 3.5.0<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FN2\">1</a></sup>. We will summarise here briefly the reduction procedure. </p>\n<p>The <i>Chandra </i>observation was tele-metered in very faint mode and was performed through both back-illuminated (BI) and front-illuminated (FI) chips. The cluster centre was imaged in the S3 BI chip. The level-1 event files were reprocessed to apply the appropriate gain maps and calibration products and to reduce the ACIS quiescent background<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FN3\">2</a></sup>. We used the acis_process_events tool to check for cosmic-ray background events and to correct for eventual spatial gain variations caused by charge transfer inefficiency to re-compute the event grades. We applied the standard event selection, including only the events flagged with grades 0,2,3,4, and filtered for the Good Time Intervals associated with the observation. The bright point sources were masked out, and a geometrical correction for the masked areas was applied; the point sources were identified using the script vtpdetect, and the result was then checked through visual inspection. </p>\n<p>A careful screening of the background light curve is necessary for a correct background subtraction (<a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R60\">Markevitch et&#160;al. 2003</a>), to discard contaminating flare events, which could have a non-negligible influence on the inferred cluster spectral properties. We extracted the background light curve, applying a time binning of about 1&#160;ks, in the energy range [2.5&#8211;7]&#160;keV, which is the most effective band to individuate common flares for S3 chip. We applied the script lc_clean to include only the time periods within a factor 1.2 of the mean quiescent rate. We compared the S3 background light curve with the light curve extracted in the S1 chip using the energy range [2.5&#8211;6]&#160;keV, to check for faint, long flares, which were not identified. The S3 background light curve was examined using the <i>ChIPS </i>facilities to identify and exclude further flaring events. The net exposure time after the light curve screening is about 31&#160;ks (see Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T1\">1</a>). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;2</span></a>\n              <p>(<i>Top left panel</i>) Deprojected gas density profile. The red circles indicate the values determined by the normalisation of the thermal spectra, while diamonds represent the values obtained combining both spectral and surface brightness measurements: the dashed line shows the best-fit profile. (<i>Bottom left panel</i>) ICM temperature profile. The figure shows the projected temperature values, directly inferred from the spectral analysis (red filled circles) and the deprojected values, which were rebinned to the same binning of the spectral profile (diamonds). The dashed line shows the deprojected best-fit profile. (<i>Right panel</i>) The projected (black empty diamonds) and deprojected (red filled circles) metallicity profile for Abell&#160;611 inferred from the X-ray analysis. The dotted line represents the mean metallicity value <i>Z</i>&#160;=&#160;(0.45&#160;&#177;&#160;0.1)&#160;&#160;<i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, as determined through the fit of the spectrum extracted in the area with radius <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;2.9&#160;arcmin, i.e. the cluster area covered by our spectral analysis. The grey region indicates the 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence level.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.2. X-ray analysis</h3>\n<p>In order to derive a reliable cluster mass estimate through the X-ray analysis, a primary issue is to avoid any bias in the temperature estimate, because cluster masses derived by assuming hydrostatic equilibrium are dependent on the temperature profile, as demonstrated by <a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R87\">Rasia et&#160;al. (2006)</a>. For this purpose, a correct background modelling is crucial. The X-ray background is often estimated through the blank-sky background data sets provided by the ACIS calibration team. The blank-sky observations are reduced similarly to the source data sets to be compatible with the cluster event files; the former are then re-normalised by comparing the blank-sky count rate in a given energy range (generally <i>kT</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;8.0&#160;keV, since in this band the <i>Chandra </i>effective area is negligible) with the local background count rate. One of the advantages of this modus operandi is that the derived ARF and RESPONSE matrices will be consistent both for the source and the background spectrum. However, the background in the X-ray soft band can vary both in time and in space, so it is important to verify whether the background derived by the blank-sky datasets is consistent with the &#8220;real&#8221; one. </p>\n<p>For this purpose, we extracted a spectrum from the <i>Chandra </i>observation in a region where the cluster emission is negligible: we compared the former to a spectrum derived in the same region of the blank-field data set. We tried to fit the residuals in the [0.4&#8211;3]&#160;keV band with a MEKAL model, without an absorption component and broadening the normalisation fitting range to negative values. This comparison shows some differences between the two spectra. For this reason, we decided to proceed in the spectral fitting utilising both a local background estimate and a blank-sky estimate. The effect of the background choice in the mass estimate results will be discussed in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S7\">2.5</a>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>2.3. Spectral fitting</h3>\n<p>The spectra were extracted on concentric annuli centred on the X-ray surface brightness centroid, each one containing at least 2500 net source counts, to infer an estimate of the ICM metallicity. We selected six annuli with adequate <i>S</i>/<i>N</i> ratio, up to <i>R</i><sub>spec</sub>&#160;=&#160;2.9 arcmin. We used the <i>CIAO </i>specextract tool to extract the source and background spectra and to construct ancillary-response and response matrices. The spectra were fitted in the 0.6&#8211;7.0&#160;keV range except for the last two annuli, in which, due to the higher background level, we restricted the analysis to the range 0.6&#8211;5.0&#160;keV. We performed the spectral analysis using the <i>XSPEC </i>software package (<a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R4\">Arnaud 1996</a>). We adopted an optically-thin plasma emission model (the mekal model; <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R68\">Mewe et&#160;al. 1985</a>; <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R45\">Kaastra &amp; Mewe 1993</a>) with an absorption component (the T&#252;bingen-Boulder model tbabs; <a name=\"InR106\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R106\">Wilms et&#160;al. 2000</a>). </p>\n<p>We fixed the Galactic absorption to the value inferred from radio HI maps in <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R26\">Dickey &amp; Lockman (1990)</a>, i.e. 4.99&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>20</sup>&#160;cm<sup>-2</sup>. The free parameters in the spectral fitting model are the temperature, the metallicity and the normalisation of the thermal spectrum. </p>\n<p>The metal abundance profile presents a central peak with a quite scattered trend (see the right panel of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F2\">2</a>). The metallicity profile is not directly involved in the X-ray mass reconstruction: but we still verified whether a bias in its measurement can influence the derived mass estimate. The results of this check will be presented in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S7\">2.5</a>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>2.4. X-ray mass profile</h3>\n<p>The gas temperature and density profiles are recovered without any parameterisation of the ICM properties, but relying on the assumptions of spherical symmetry and hydrostatic equilibrium and on the choice of a model for the total mass. </p>\n<p>The method that was applied is briefly resumed in the following; the reader can refer to <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R30\">Ettori et&#160;al. (2002); </a><a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R71\">Morandi et&#160;al. (2007); </a><a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R70\">Morandi &amp; Ettori (2007)</a> for full details. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;3</span></a>\n              <p>(<i>Left panel</i>) Mass profiles for Abell&#160;611 as determined through the X-ray analysis. The black solid line and the red dashed line indicate the total mass and the gas mass profile, respectively. (<i>Right panel</i>) Confidence levels determined through the X-ray analysis for the NFW profile parameters <i>r</i><sub>s</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>. The red circle indicates the best-fit values, while the contours represent the 1<i>&#963;,</i>2<i>&#963;</i>, and 3<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;2</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit values for the total mass parameters obtained through the X-ray analysis.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In this section, the subscript &#8220;ring&#8221; will indicate a projected quantity measured in concentric rings (equivalently, spectral bins), whereas the subscript &#8220;shell&#8221; will point to a deprojected quantity measured in volume shells. The projected gas temperature <i>T</i><sub>ring</sub>, metal abundance <i>Z</i><sub>ring</sub> and the normalisation <i>K</i><sub>ring</sub> of the model for each annulus are derived through the spectral analysis. In particular, the normalisation of the thermal spectrum provides an estimate for the emission integral <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq54.png\"></span>. </p>\n<p>To deproject the former quantities, we need to derive the intersection of each volume shell with the spectral annuli, which can be calculated through an upper triangular matrix <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq55.png\"></span>, whose last pivot represents the outermost annulus if we assume spherical symmetry (<a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R53\">Kriss et&#160;al. 1983</a>; <a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R20\">Buote 2000</a>). </p>\n<p>To calculate the deprojected density profile, we combined the spectral information and the cluster X-ray surface brightness (SB) profile, composed by 15 bins with 1000&#160;counts each. The SB provides an estimate of the volume-counts emissivity <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq56.png\"></span>, where <i>D</i><sub>L</sub> is the luminosity distance of the cluster. By comparing this observed profile with the values predicted by a thermal plasma model, with temperature and metallicity equal to the measured spectral quantities and taking into account the absorption effect, we can solve for the electron density and obtain a gas density profile better resolved than a &#8220;spectral-only&#8221; one (see the top panel of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F2\">2</a>). </p>\n<p>The total gravitating mass was then constrained as follows: the observed deprojected temperature profile in volume shells <i>T</i><sub>shell</sub> was obtained through <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq59.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>where <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq60.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>here the symbol # indicates a matrix product, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq55.png\"></span> is the volume matrix and <i>L</i><sub>ring</sub> is the cluster luminosity measured in concentric rings. We compare it to the predicted temperature profile <i>T</i><sub>model</sub>, obtained by inverting the equation of hydrostatic equilibrium between the dark matter and the intracluster plasma, i.e.: <a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq64.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span>where <i>n</i><sub>e</sub> is the deprojected electron density. Our best-fit mass model was determined by comparing the observed temperature profile <i>T</i><sub>&#160;&#8201;&#160;obs</sub> with the predicted profile <i>T</i><sub>&#160;&#8201;&#160;model</sub>, which depends on the mass model parameters: accordingly we minimised the quantity: <a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq68.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span>where the <i>T</i><sub>model</sub> profile was rebinned to match the observed temperature profile. In the bottom panel of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F2\">2</a> we show the projected temperature profile as determined through the spectral analysis, the deprojected best-fit profile and the deprojected profile, rebinned to the spectral intervals. </p>\n<p>We assumed the NFW profile as the total mass functional; this profile can be expressed as: <a name=\"FD5\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq69.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(5)</span></span>where <i>&#961;</i><sub>s</sub> is the characteristic density and <i>r</i><sub>s</sub> is the scale radius. We will describe the NFW profile through the scale radius and the concentration parameter <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>; the former can be defined as <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq71.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(6)</span></span>where <i>R</i><sub>200</sub> is the radius within which the mean matter density of the halo is 200 times the critical density of the Universe. Assuming a mass model, the best-fitting values of its parameters are determined by minimising the quantity defined in Eq.&#160;(<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FD4\">4</a>). The NFW profile parameters were optimised in the ranges <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq73.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-eq74.png\"></span>, where the scale radius upper limit is the outer radius of the surface brightness profile. The gas and total mass profiles are shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F3\">3</a>; the inferred mass model parameters are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T2\">2</a>. The confidence levels for the NFW parameters are shown in the right panel of Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F3\">3</a>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>2.5. Systematic effects in the X-ray mass profile</h3>\n<p>In this section we will briefly assess if our X-ray mass estimate of Abell&#160;611 can be affected by some analysis choices. </p>\n<p>The choice of the X-ray background estimate, as discussed in Sect.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#S4\">2.2</a>, could have a non-negligible impact on the derived temperature profile, and consequently on the total mass measurement. Moreover, we verified whether considering the ICM metallicity as a free parameter in the spectral analysis can impact the X-ray mass estimate of Abell&#160;611, since (as shown in Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F2\">2</a>) its inferred metallicity profile is quite irregular. We thus re-ran the spectral analysis by fixing the metallicity <i>Z</i> to the typical value of 0.3&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> (see e.g.  <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R5\">Balestra et&#160;al. 2007</a>); we then derived a new X-ray mass estimate adopting the spectral profiles obtained under the assumption of a constant metallicity. </p>\n<p>Therefore we derived the mass of Abell&#160;611 through the X-ray analysis:</p>\n<p><ul style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\n<li>1. <p class=\"ligne\"> by estimating the X-ray background through the spectra extracted from the blank-sky dataset (opportunely reprocessed and re-normalised to be consistent with the source observations) in the same image regions used for the source spectra (case 1); </p>\n</li>\n<li>2. <p class=\"ligne\"> by estimating the X-ray background from peripheral regions of the S3 chip in the source dataset (case 2); </p>\n</li>\n<li>3. <p class=\"ligne\"> as in the previous case, but by fixing the metallicity <i>Z</i> to the value 0.3&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> (case 3). </p>\n</li>\n</ul>The NFW parameters derived from the X-ray analysis in the three aforementioned cases are listed in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T2\">2</a>. </p>\n<p>The results obtained in the first two cases mutually agree within the 1<i>&#963;</i> range, even if the temperature profile derived in the latter case is systematically higher (see Fig.&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#F4\">4</a>). Moreover, the best-fit parameters obtained in the third case (i.e. fixing the metallicity to 0.3&#160;&#160;&#160;<i>Z</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>: see case 3 in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T2\">2</a>) agree with the values obtained by including the metallicity as a free parameter in the fitting: the choice of estimating or fixing the metallicity in the spectral analysis has a negligible impact on the derived cluster mass. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig.&#8201;4</span></a>\n              <p>Comparison between the temperature profile determined by estimating the X-ray background through the blank-sky dataset (red dashed line) or using a local background component (black solid line).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3. Strong lensing analysis</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3.1. Imaging data</h3>\n<p>Our strong lensing analysis of Abell&#160;611 benefits from the high-resolution imaging data obtained with the <i>Hubble </i>Space Telescope (HST), which allowed an unambiguous identification of several lensed systems. Abell&#160;611 was observed with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) mounted on HST. We retrieved the ACS association data of Abell&#160;611 from the Multimission Archive at STScI (MAST)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FN4\">3</a></sup>; the details of the HST observation of Abell&#160;611 are summarised in Table&#160;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#T3\">3</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;3</span></a>\n              <p>Observation summary of the ACS/HST image used for the strong lensing analysis.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table&#160;4</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit parameters obtained by modelling the galaxy luminosity with the S&#233;rsic profile (<a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R98\">Sersic 1968</a>).</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>The HST archival data for Abell&#160;611 are already processed following the ACS pipeline and combined using the multidrizzle software (<a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R50\">Koekemoer et&#160;al. 2002</a>), with a final pixel scale of 0.05&#160;arcsec; consequently no additional basic data reduction is necessary. But we used the softwares <i>SExtractor </i>(<a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R11\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>), <i>Scamp </i>(<a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R10\">Bertin 2006</a>) and <i>Swarp</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#FN5\">4</a></sup> (<a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2011/04/aa14120-10/aa14120-10.html#R12\">Bertin et&#160;al. 2002</a>), developed at the TERAPIX data reduction centre to derive the object catalogue for the Abell&#160;611 HST imaging data, re-compute an astrometric solution and finally resample the image to derive a more accurate astrometric matching and to equalise the background level. The WCS coordinates reported in the present work are given with regard to the HST data and refer to the astrometric solution that we re-derived. Abell&#160;611 was also observed during the Science Demonstration Time for the Blue Channel of the Large Binocular Camera (LBC), mounted at the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) (located at the Mt.
